text: victims of typhoon haiyan may be getting
aid now but they still need to look out
themselves here's five examples of what
they're doing to survive in the
aftermath of the storm number one
shelter many who lost their homes have
nowhere to go and no roof over their
heads so they're using what's left of
their old homes to build new shelters
they're working fast and all parts of
the house are gained a common worry is
if another storm hits their families
won't happen in protection number two
water this man's neighbor allowed him to
tap into a water pipe under his property
local residents used this public supply
for things like drinking and laundry
there's even an on-off level to control
this precious resource number three fuel
this man sells bottles of diesel fuel by
the road as a way to make some extra
money he says he got the fuel from an
abandoned gas station in the aftermath
of the storm and there are plenty more
decent stands just like this number for
food this family always had pigs and
they always slaughter the animals for
their own consumption but not anymore
they slaughtered this pig specifically
for selling and like the diesel man
making extra cash this was the first
time they done anything like this and
finally number five flight for some
survival means leaving Tacloban
altogether this family is hoping to stay
with relatives in Manila but it's not so
easy if you don't have money they have
to join this queue already 200 meters
long at nine thirty in the morning here
people will wait hours maybe days for
the free flights on military aircraft
but even if you wait a seat is not
guaranteed David Botti BBC News Tacloban
